div.p: a most Hogish race of beings, for the 2 y Men to whom the cache belonged, are the same 2 whom we overtook the 12th of October, altho we passed quite close to it, & that they well knew we were in great want of Provissions, yet they did not mention a syllable concerning the said Cache, but kept continually saying that they were very Pittyfull & had nothing &c &c[.] What a Mean Lying set of Rascals for my part I am quite Tired of telling them so[.] N.B. The Indians when they came here the other day brought 2 small Bales of Meat for Martin & St André which they said Martin desired them to give to his Wife & that she would pay them an awl & a little vermillion for their Trouble[.] I would not allow them to give it to her but Traded it myself & at the same time told them that Martin nor any other had no Right to Trade with them[.] I was at the time very much surprised at their Impudence for I could not conceive how they dared have the Insolence to act in that Manner – had some Cross words with Martin concerning it, for this Gentleman it seems is very much disspleased at my having Traded the said Meat – & Loudly swears vengance against the Indian that gave it to him – for he says he did not Trade it as the Indian to whom it belonged voluntarily made him a present of it[.] I told him that had I known at the time I would not have traded it – but if he took vengance upon the Indian I would take vengance upon him, for it was not his fault if he did not give the Meat to his Wife, but that it was me who would not allow him – as I at that time thought that he meet those Indians coming to the Fort with Meat & that he had the impudence & Hoggishness to trade some from them &c[.] What a Dirty despicable set of fellons they are for Altho I give them as many Hares as they can Cram in their voracious Guts, & that they well
